questions.title: Series Inductors Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the total inductance when two inductors $L_1 = 5\,\text{H}$ and $L_2 = 5\,\text{H}$ are connected in series. Express answer in henries (H).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For series inductors: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2 = 5\,\text{H} + 5\,\text{H} = 10\,\text{H}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use series formula: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2$. Series inductors add directly like resistors.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the total inductance when two inductors $L_1 = 6\,\text{H}$ and $L_2 = 6\,\text{H}$ are connected in parallel. Express answer in henries (H).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For parallel inductors: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2 = 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/3$, so $L_{\text{total}} = 3\,\text{H}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use parallel formula: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2$. For equal inductors: $L_{\text{total}} = L/n$ where $n$ is the number of inductors.

questions.title: Right-Hand Rule for Magnetic Field
questions.question_text: Using the right-hand rule to determine magnetic field direction around a current-carrying wire:
questions.correct_answer: Thumb = current direction, fingers curl = $\vec{B}$ direction
choices: Thumb = current direction, fingers curl = $\vec{B}$ direction
Thumb = $\vec{B}$ direction, fingers curl = current direction
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Right-hand rule: thumb points in current direction, fingers curl in direction of magnetic field $\vec{B}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Right-hand rule: align thumb with current direction, curved fingers show magnetic field $\vec{B}$ direction.

questions.title: Factors NOT Affecting Inductance
questions.question_text: When calculating the inductance $L$ of a coil using $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$, which parameter does NOT affect the result?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Wire resistance R affects power loss but not inductance L. Inductance depends on geometry and permeability.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Inductance L depends on turns N, area A, length $\ell$, and permeability $\mu$. Wire resistance is separate from inductance.

questions.title: Core Permeability Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: How does the relative permeability $\mu_r$ of the core material affect inductance in the formula $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Higher $\mu_r$ increases magnetic flux density $\vec{B} = \mu\vec{H}$, enhancing magnetic coupling and inductance L.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Permeability $\mu_r$ affects how well the core material supports magnetic fields, directly influencing inductance.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Formula
questions.question_text: For three inductors $L_1$, $L_2$, and $L_3$ connected in parallel, which formula correctly calculates total inductance?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Parallel inductors combine like parallel resistors: reciprocal of total equals sum of reciprocals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Parallel inductors: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2 + 1/L_3$. This is opposite to series combination.

questions.title: Inductor Energy Storage Mechanism
questions.question_text: An inductor stores energy in an electric field between its windings.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductors store energy in magnetic fields: $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Capacitors store energy in electric fields.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductors store energy in magnetic fields ($E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$), while capacitors store energy in electric fields.

questions.title: Series Inductors Combination Rule
questions.question_text: The total inductance of inductors connected in series equals the sum of their individual inductances: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2 + ... + L_n$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Series inductors add directly: $L_{\text{total}} = \sum L_i$, similar to series resistors.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. Series inductors combine by direct addition, just like series resistors.

questions.title: Turn Count Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: The inductance of a coil decreases when the number of turns $N$ increases, keeping all other parameters constant.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductance $L \propto N^2$ increases quadratically with turn count due to increased magnetic flux linkage.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductance $L \propto N^2$ increases with the square of the number of turns.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Total Value
questions.question_text: When inductors are connected in parallel, the total inductance $L_{\text{total}}$ is always smaller than the smallest individual inductor value.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Parallel combination: $1/L_{\text{total}} = \sum(1/L_i)$ always gives $L_{\text{total}} < L_{\text{min}}$, like parallel resistors.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. Parallel combination always reduces total inductance below the smallest individual value.

questions.title: Coil Diameter Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: A coil with larger diameter (cross-sectional area $A$) has lower inductance than a smaller diameter coil, assuming all other factors remain constant.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! From $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$, inductance $L \propto A$ increases with cross-sectional area (diameter$^2$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Larger diameter increases area A, which increases inductance $L \propto A$ in the inductance formula.

questions.title: Inductor Voltage-Current Rate Relationship
questions.question_text: The voltage across an inductor $V_L$ is directly proportional to the rate of change of current through it ($dI_L/dt$).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Faraday's law gives $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$, showing direct proportionality between voltage and current rate.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. The fundamental inductor equation $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$ shows this direct proportionality.

questions.title: Constant Current Through Inductor
questions.question_text: When current through an inductor is constant ($dI_L/dt = 0$), the voltage across the inductor equals zero.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $V_L = L(dI_L/dt) = L(0) = 0\,\text{V}$ when current is constant. Inductor acts like short circuit for DC steady state.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. From $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$, constant current ($dI_L/dt = 0$) results in zero voltage across the inductor.

questions.title: Inductor Energy Storage Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the energy stored in a $2\,\text{H}$ inductor carrying a steady current of $3\,\text{A}$. Use $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Express answer in joules (J).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Substitute: $L = 2\,\text{H}$, $I = 3\,\text{A}$. Calculate: $\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 3^2 = 9\,\text{J}$.

questions.title: Coil Length Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: For a given coil with fixed turns $N$, cross-sectional area $A$, and permeability $\mu$, a shorter coil length $\ell$ results in higher inductance $L$ according to $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! From $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$, inductance is inversely proportional to coil length. Shorter $\ell$ increases magnetic flux density.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. The inductance formula $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$ shows inverse relationship with length $\ell$.

questions.title: Wire Resistance in Inductance Formula
questions.question_text: The inductance formula $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$ includes the DC resistance of the wire used to construct the coil.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductance L depends only on geometry (N, A, $\ell$) and magnetic permeability $\mu$. Wire resistance R is a separate parasitic parameter.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductance is determined by magnetic properties, not wire resistance. R and L are independent parameters.

questions.title: Circuit Node Definition
questions.question_text: In circuit analysis, what precisely defines a node?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A node is a connection point where two or more circuit elements meet, defining a common voltage point.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A node is an electrical junction point where multiple components connect, establishing a common potential.

questions.title: Circuit Branch Definition
questions.question_text: A branch in circuit analysis is best characterized as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A branch connects two distinct nodes and may contain one or more circuit elements in series.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A branch is a current path connecting two nodes, potentially containing circuit components.

questions.title: Circuit Loop Definition
questions.question_text: What defines a loop in circuit topology?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A loop is a closed path starting and ending at the same node without traversing any branch twice.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A loop must be a closed path that returns to its starting node without retracing any branches.

questions.title: Node Count in Series Circuit
questions.question_text: A circuit contains three resistors $R_1$, $R_2$, $R_3$ connected in series with a voltage source. How many nodes are present in this circuit?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Series circuit has $n+1$ nodes for $n$ components: 4 nodes connecting 3 resistors plus voltage source.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Count connection points: each series component creates a new node between adjacent elements.

questions.title: Simple Battery-Resistor Circuit Branches
questions.question_text: In a basic circuit with one battery connected to one resistor, how many branches exist?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Each component (battery and resistor) forms a separate branch connecting the two circuit nodes.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Each component forms its own branch. Battery = 1 branch, Resistor = 1 branch, Total = 2 branches.

questions.title: Minimum Branches for Loop Formation
questions.question_text: Given a circuit with exactly 3 nodes, what is the minimum number of branches required to create at least one closed loop?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Three branches connecting three nodes can form a triangular loop (smallest possible closed path).
questions.feedback_incorrect: For 3 nodes to form a loop, you need 3 branches creating a triangular circuit topology.

questions.title: Wire Crossing Convention in Schematics
questions.question_text: In circuit diagrams, when two wires cross without a connection dot, this indicates:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Standard convention: crossing wires without dots are not connected. Dots ($\bullet$) indicate electrical connections.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Schematic convention: no dot = no connection. Only dots ($\bullet$) at intersections indicate electrical connections.

questions.title: Parallel Circuit Loop Count
questions.question_text: A circuit contains one battery and three resistors connected in parallel. How many independent loops can be identified?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Each parallel resistor creates its own loop with the battery: 3 independent current paths.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Each parallel branch forms a loop with the voltage source. Count: $R_1$-battery, $R_2$-battery, $R_3$-battery loops.

questions.title: Importance of Circuit Topology Concepts
questions.question_text: Why are nodes, branches, and loops fundamental to circuit analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! These concepts enable Kirchhoff's laws, nodal analysis, mesh analysis, and network theorems.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Circuit topology (nodes, branches, loops) provides the mathematical framework for applying Kirchhoff's laws and network analysis.

questions.title: Extended Node Definition
questions.question_text: In complex circuits with connecting wires, how is a single node properly defined?
questions.correct_answer: All points connected by ideal wires
choices: All points connected by ideal wires
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A node includes all points at the same potential, connected by ideal wires (zero resistance).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A node encompasses all points connected by ideal conductors, forming an equipotential region.

questions.title: Water Flow Rate Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic-electrical analogies, water flow rate (L/s) best represents which electrical quantity?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Flow rate corresponds to current $I = dQ/dt$ (charge flow rate). Both measure flow per unit time.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Water flow rate (volume/time) analogously represents electric current (charge/time).

questions.title: Water Pressure Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic analogies, water pressure (Pa) corresponds to which electrical parameter?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pressure difference drives water flow, just as voltage difference drives electric current.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Water pressure provides the driving force for flow, analogous to voltage as the driving force for current.

questions.title: Flow Restriction Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic analogies, a narrow pipe restricting water flow represents which circuit element?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pipe restrictions oppose flow ($\propto$ pressure/flow), just as resistors oppose current ($V = IR$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Flow restriction corresponds to electrical resistance - both oppose the flow of their respective quantities.

questions.title: Water Pump Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: What electrical component corresponds to a water pump creating pressure difference in hydraulic systems?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pumps create pressure difference ($\Delta P$), while batteries create voltage difference ($\Delta V = V_+ - V_-$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Water pumps provide the energy to create pressure difference, analogous to batteries creating voltage difference.

questions.title: Closed Valve Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic analogies, a closed valve or disconnected pipe represents which circuit condition?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Closed valves stop flow ($I = 0$), just as open circuits prevent current flow.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Closed valves block flow completely, analogous to open circuits preventing current flow.

questions.title: Pipe Dimensions Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: Pipe diameter and length affecting water flow correspond to which electrical property?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $R = \rho L/A$ shows resistance depends on length L and area A, just as pipe flow depends on dimensions.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Pipe geometry affects flow resistance, analogous to how conductor geometry determines electrical resistance.

questions.title: Rubber Membrane Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: A stretchable rubber membrane in a pipe that stores pressure corresponds to which electrical component?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Membranes store pressure energy ($\propto \Delta P^2$), while capacitors store electric energy ($E = \frac{1}{2}CV^2$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Elastic membranes store pressure energy, analogous to capacitors storing electrical energy in electric fields.

questions.title: Bypass Pipe Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: A large bypass pipe allowing excessive water flow around obstacles represents which dangerous circuit condition?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Bypass pipes allow uncontrolled flow, like short circuits allowing dangerous current bypassing normal resistance.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Large bypass pipes create uncontrolled flow paths, analogous to short circuits bypassing intended circuit resistance.

questions.title: Ground Reference in Circuit Analysis
questions.question_text: In circuit analysis, what is the primary function of the ground reference symbol ($\unicode{x2314}$)?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Ground establishes the zero-volt reference point for all voltage measurements in the circuit.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Ground serves as the 0V reference point for measuring voltages throughout the circuit.

questions.title: Node Voltage Interpretation
questions.question_text: When stating 'the voltage at node A is 5V,' what does this measurement specifically represent?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Node voltages are always measured relative to the ground reference ($V_A = 5\,\text{V}$ means $V_A - V_{\text{ground}} = 5\,\text{V}$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Voltage measurements are relative to ground: $V_A = 5\,\text{V}$ means the potential difference between node A and ground.

questions.title: True Ground vs Circuit Ground
questions.question_text: What distinguishes 'true ground' from 'circuit ground' in modern electrical design?
questions.correct_answer: True ground = Earth potential, circuit ground = 0V reference
choices: True ground = Earth potential, circuit ground = 0V reference
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! True ground connects to Earth's potential (safety), while circuit ground is simply a chosen 0V reference point.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True ground physically connects to Earth's potential, while circuit ground is an arbitrary 0V reference point.

questions.title: Differential Voltage Measurement
questions.question_text: When measuring voltage 'across' a resistor $R_1$ not connected to ground, what type of measurement is this?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Differential voltage measures $V_{R1} = V_+ - V_-$ between two arbitrary points, not referenced to ground.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Voltage 'across' implies differential measurement: $V_{R1} = V_{\text{node1}} - V_{\text{node2}}$, independent of ground reference.

questions.title: Circuit Node Definition
questions.question_text: What precisely defines a node in electrical circuit topology?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A node is a junction where two or more circuit elements connect, establishing a common potential point.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A node is defined as a connection point where multiple circuit elements meet.

questions.title: Circuit Branch Characteristics
questions.question_text: How is a branch properly characterized in circuit analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A branch is a current path between two nodes, potentially containing circuit elements in series.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A branch connects exactly two nodes and may contain one or more circuit elements.

questions.title: Circuit Loop Properties
questions.question_text: What fundamental property defines a loop in circuit topology?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A loop is a closed path that returns to its starting node without traversing any branch twice.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A loop must form a closed path that starts and ends at the same node without retracing branches.

questions.title: Water Flow Rate Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic-electrical analogies, water flow rate (L/s) corresponds to which electrical quantity?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Flow rate represents current $I = dQ/dt$ (charge flow per unit time), both measuring flow quantities.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Water flow rate (volume/time) analogously represents electric current (charge/time).

questions.title: Water Pressure Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic analogies, water pressure (Pa) represents which electrical parameter?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pressure difference $\Delta P$ drives water flow, just as voltage difference $\Delta V$ drives electric current.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Water pressure provides the driving force for flow, analogous to voltage driving current.

questions.title: Pipe Geometry Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: Pipe diameter and length affecting hydraulic flow correspond to which electrical property described by $R = \rho\ell/A$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Hydraulic resistance $\propto \ell/d^2$ and electrical resistance $R = \rho\ell/A$ both depend on geometry.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Pipe geometry affects flow resistance, directly analogous to how conductor geometry determines electrical resistance.

questions.title: Elastic Membrane Electrical Analogy
questions.question_text: In hydraulic-electrical analogies, a stretchable rubber membrane in a pipe that stores pressure energy corresponds to which electrical component?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The membrane stores pressure energy ($E \propto \Delta P^2$), analogous to capacitors storing electric energy ($E = \frac{1}{2}CV^2$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: The elastic membrane stores pressure energy, similar to how capacitors store electrical energy in electric fields.

questions.title: Ground Reference Function
questions.question_text: What is the primary function of the ground reference symbol ($\unicode{x2314}$) in circuit analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Ground establishes the zero-volt reference point ($V_{\text{ground}} = 0\,\text{V}$) for all voltage measurements in the circuit.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Ground serves as the 0V reference point. All node voltages are measured relative to this reference.

questions.title: Node Voltage Interpretation
questions.question_text: When stating 'the voltage at node A is 5V,' what does this measurement specifically represent?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Node voltages are always measured relative to ground reference: $V_A = 5\,\text{V}$ means $V_A - V_{\text{ground}} = 5\,\text{V} - 0\,\text{V} = 5\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Node voltage measurements are relative to ground reference. $V_A = 5\,\text{V}$ means the potential difference between node A and ground.

questions.title: True Ground vs Circuit Ground Distinction
questions.question_text: What distinguishes 'true ground' from 'circuit ground' in electrical engineering practice?
questions.correct_answer: True ground = Earth potential, circuit ground = 0V reference
choices: True ground = Earth potential, circuit ground = 0V reference
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! True ground physically connects to Earth's potential (safety ground), while circuit ground is an arbitrary chosen 0V reference point for voltage measurements.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True ground connects to Earth's actual potential for safety, while circuit ground is simply a convenient 0V reference point.

questions.title: Differential Voltage Measurement
questions.question_text: When measuring voltage 'across' a resistor $R_1$ that is not connected to ground, what type of measurement is this?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Differential voltage measures $V_{R1} = V_+ - V_-$ between two arbitrary points, independent of ground reference.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Voltage 'across' implies differential measurement: $V_{R1} = V_{\text{node1}} - V_{\text{node2}}$, measured between two arbitrary points.

questions.title: Phasor to Time Domain Conversion
questions.question_text: Convert the phasor $V = 120\angle 0\text{\degree}\,\text{V}$ at $\omega = 377\,\text{rad/s}$ to its time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For phasor $V\angle\theta$, the time domain form is $v(t) = V \cos(\omega t + \theta)$. Here: $v(t) = 120\cos(377t + 0\text{\degree}) = 120\cos(377t)\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: For phasor $V\angle\theta$, use $v(t) = V \cos(\omega t + \theta)$. With $\theta = 0\text{\degree}$, the result is $v(t) = 120\cos(377t)\,\text{V}$.

questions.title: Current Phasor with Phase Shift
questions.question_text: Convert the phasor $I = 3.5\angle -30\text{\degree}\,\text{A}$ at $\omega = 50\pi\,\text{rad/s}$ to time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For phasor $I\angle\theta$, the time domain form is $i(t) = I \cos(\omega t + \theta) = 3.5\cos(50\pi t - 30\text{\degree})\,\text{A}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the conversion formula $i(t) = I \cos(\omega t + \theta)$ for phasor $I\angle\theta$. The phase angle is preserved in the cosine argument.

questions.title: Complex Number to Time Domain
questions.question_text: Convert the complex number $X = 5 + j3$ at $\omega = 100\,\text{rad/s}$ to time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $|X| = \sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = 5.83$, $\theta = \arctan(3/5) = 30.96\text{\degree}$. Therefore $x(t) = 5.83\cos(100t + 30.96\text{\degree})$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Convert to polar form: magnitude = $\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}$, phase = $\arctan(b/a)$, then use $x(t) = |X|\cos(\omega t + \theta)$.

questions.title: Third Quadrant Complex Number
questions.question_text: Convert the complex number $F = -4 - j2$ at $\omega = 25\pi\,\text{rad/s}$ to time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $|F| = \sqrt{(-4)^2 + (-2)^2} = 4.47$, $\theta = \arctan(-2/-4) - 180\text{\degree} = -153.43\text{\degree}$ (third quadrant adjustment).
questions.feedback_incorrect: For third quadrant: magnitude = $\sqrt{a^2 + b^2}$, phase = $\arctan(b/a) \pm 180\text{\degree}$ to place in correct quadrant.

questions.title: AC Voltage Phasor Conversion
questions.question_text: Convert the phasor $V = 220\angle 45\text{\degree}\,\text{V}$ at $\omega = 314\,\text{rad/s}$ to time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Direct phasor-to-time conversion: $V\angle\theta \to V \cos(\omega t + \theta) = 220\cos(314t + 45\text{\degree})\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: For phasor $V\angle\theta$, the time domain representation is $v(t) = V \cos(\omega t + \theta)$. Phase angle is preserved.
